choices.text: Levetiracetam
Phenytoin
Topiramate
Sodium Valproate

questions.text: A baby is born to a mother who is epileptic. It is observed that the toes and fingers of the baby appear short and also the facial appearance appears different to the mother. She asks the doctor if any drug she was taking could have caused these features. Which is the most likely drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phenytoin

  • These are features of fetal hydantoin syndrome
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome is characterized by
  • Facial features: midfacial hypoplasia, upturned nose
  • Distal digital hypoplasia

 

  • It is characteristically seen with phenytoin; also seen with phenobarbitone and carbamazepine

Other Options

  • Topiramate causes cleft lip and palate
  • Na valproate has a very high incidence of teratogenicity and causes NTD, cardiac anomalies and clefting
  • Levetiracetam is the safest antiepileptic and least teratogenic

 

Ref: Williams Page no 2941 (Chapter 63), Williams 26th edition

choices.text: 2%
5%
12%
15%

questions.text: When a pregnant woman has a congenital heart disease, the risk of the fetus having a congenital heart disease is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5%

Congenital Heart Disease in the pregnant woman

  • When a pregnant woman has a congenital heart disease, the fetus is at increased risk for congenital heart disease
  • The risk is about 3-10% but can vary depending on the type of disease.
  • When the fetus is affected, 50% will have the same anomaly as the mother

Ref: Page no 902, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Cardiomyopathy
Congenital heart disease
Myocardial Infarction
Rheumatic heart disease

questions.text: The most common heart disease in pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rheumatic heart disease

  • The incidence of heart disease in pregnancy is less than 1%
  • The most common cardiac lesion is of rheumatic origin followed by congenital heart disease.

Ref: Page no 257, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Class I
Class II
Class III
Class IV

questions.text: A 34-year woman, known case of mitral stenosis presents to the antenatal OPD at 28 weeks with symptoms of breathlessness on walking upstairs. According to New York Heart Association (NYHA) Classification, which grade is she in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Class II.

The clinical classification of the New York Heart Association (NYHA) is based on past and present disability and is uninfluenced by physical signs.

As this patient is symptomatic (marked limitation) on physical activity (climbing stairs) she is NYHA Class 2

Educational Objective: 

 

Ref: Page no 951, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Nuva ring
Transdermal patch
Combined OCP
LNG-IUS

questions.text: A 21-year-old recently married woman approaches the gynecologist for contraceptive counselling. She is a known epileptic on carbamazepine. Which contraceptive will you offer her?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. LNG-US

  • Women taking enzyme-inducing AEDs (carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, primidone, oxcarbazepine, topiramate and eslicarbazepine) should be counselled about the risk of failure with some hormonal contraceptives.
  • Women should be counselled that the efficacy of
  • Oral contraceptives (combined hormonal contraception, progestogen-only pills)
  • Transdermal patches
  • Vaginal ring and
  • Progestogen-only implants

may be affected if they are taking enzyme-inducing AEDs (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, primidone, oxcarbazepine and eslicarbazepine).

  • All methods of contraception may be offered to women taking non-enzyme-inducing AEDs (e.g., sodium valproate, levetiracetam, gabapentin, vigabatrin, tiagabine and pregabalin).

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/media/rzldnacf/gtg68_epilepsy.pdf

choices.text: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
Loud S1 with splitting
Pansystolic murmur
Systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border

questions.text: A 26 yr. primi presents to the antenatal OPD at 30 weeks of gestation. She is an un-booked patient and complains of increasing breathlessness and occasional palpitations. Which of the following signs is not found in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pansystolic murmur.

Normal Cardiovascular findings in pregnancy

  • Tachycardia
  • Ejection systolic murmur at aortic and pulmonary area
  • Apex beat shifted to 4th intercostal space 1.5 cm lateral to mid clavicular line
  • Loud S1
  • Mammary souffle
  • Venous hum
  • S3
  • Occasional S4

Educational Objective:

Clinical Indicators of Heart Disease during Pregnancy

 

Ref: Page no 950, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Primary pulmonary hypertension
NYHA class 3 or 4
Eisenmenger’s syndrome
Ischemic Heart Disease

questions.text: A 32 yr. G3P2L2 presents to the antenatal OPD at 8 weeks gestation. She is a known case of heart disease in pregnancy. All of the following are indications for termination of pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ischemic Heart disease

Considering a high maternal mortality in certain conditions; the following are absolute indications of termination of pregnancy (WHO Class 4)

Educational Objective: 

Conditions in which women should avoid getting pregnant (Pregnancy is CONTRA-INDICATED)

  • Pulmonary Artery Hypertension
  • Severe systolic Hypertension (EF < 30%)
  • Moderate systemic right ventricular dysfunction
  • Severe mitral stenosis
  • Severe symotomatic aortic stenosis
  • Severe aortic dilatation
  • Vascular Ehlor Danlos
  • Severe re (coarctation)
  • Fontan with any complication

 

Ref: Page no 951, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Epidural analgesia
IV Fluids @100ml/ h to maintain hydration
Forceps in the 2nd stage of labor
O2 via nasal prongs

questions.text: A 30 yr. primigravida at 37 weeks presents in labor. She is a known case of mitral stenosis, NYHA Class 1. On examination, the uterus is term size, contractions are present, and FHR is 130 bpm. Vaginal examination reveals a 4 cm dilated cervix, well effaced with vertex presentation. Which is NOT recommended?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  IV fluids @100ml/hr to maintain hydration

Let's Discuss all the Options

Option A: Epidural analgesia: Epidural analgesia is recommended in patients with heart disease in labor. 

Option B: IV Fluids @100ml/h to maintain hydration: This should NOT be given in patients with heart diseaset o avoid volume overload. Oral intake should be recommended

Option C: Forceps in the 2nd stage of labor: The 2nd stage of labor should be cut short in heart disease patients by forceps or vacuum as this reduces the strain on the mother in the 2nd stage of labor

Option D: O2 via nasal prongs: O2 should be administered prophylactically to women with heart disease to ensure adequate oxygenation of tissues 

Eductional Objective: 

Management of Labor in Heart disease

  • Adequate analgesia (epidural preferred)
  • Avoid IV fluids due to fluid overload (Prefer oral intake)
  • Discourage ambulation
  • Rest
  • Oxygen
  • Keep anti failure drugs ready at hand
  • IE prophylaxis if indicated
  • Cut short 2nd stage of labor (Forceps preferred over vacuum)
  • Avoid methylergometrine

Indications for IE Prophylaxis in vaginal delivery/ cesarean (ACOG)

 1. Congenital heart disease (CHD)

  • Unrepaired cyanotic cardiac disease
  • Completely repaired CHD, using prosthetic material or device
  • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or device

2. Prosthetic valves

3. Previous infectious endocarditis

4. Cardiac transplant recipients with valve regurgitation to abnormal valve

 

 

Ref: Page no 951, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: High dose monotherapy
Hyperemesis gravidarum
Multiple seizure types
Sleep deprivation

questions.text: Factors contributing to poor seizure control in pregnancy include all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. High dose monotherapy

Factors that can contribute to poor seizure control during pregnancy

  1. Poor control (reduced seizure free interval) prior to conception
  2. Multiple seizure types
  3. High dose poly-therapy
  4. Poor compliance to AEDs
  5. Pregnancy specific triggers like nausea and vomiting which may reduce the drug concentration sleep deprivation and labor (pain and hyperventilation).

 

Ref:  Page no, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Folic acid 5 mg to be started pre-conceptionally and continued throughout pregnancy
Single anti-epileptic drug at the least dose is preferred during pregnancy
Sodium valproate is safe and can be continued safely
There is an increased risk of developing childhood epilepsy in the fetus

questions.text: A 25 y primigravida with a known history of epilepsy on sodium valproate presents to the antenatal OPD at 6 weeks. All are advised except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sodium valproate is safe and can be continued safely

Pregnancy and epilepsy

  • Generally low risk to the fetus.
  • There is an increased risk of major congenital malformations due to AEDs (Table 1). However certain AEDS like lamotrigine, levetiracetam and carbamazepine are commonly used and considered the safest agents. Poly-therapy increases the risk of malformations.
  • Sodium valproate infers the highest risk of congenital malformations (especially Neural tube defects).
  • Increased risk of Fetal growth restriction in women on AEDs.
  • There is an increased risk of developing childhood epilepsy in the fetus.
  • Folic acid (5mg) should be taken pre conceptionally and throughout pregnancy to reduce the risk of congenital malformations and long-term cognitive effects
  • Aim for monotherapy with the longest effective AED dose if possible. If taking sodium valproate, this needs to be changed to an alternative AED

Ref:  William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Woman on anti-epileptic drugs
Type 2 diabetes in pregnancy
Mitral stenosis in pregnancy
SLE in pregnancy

questions.text: All are indications of fetal echocardiography in pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mitral stenosis in pregnancy

The following are indications for doing a fetal ECHO

  1. Suspected fetal cardiac anomaly
  2. Extra-cardiac anomaly in the fetus
  3. Fetal chromosomal anomaly
  4. Fetal arrhythmia
  5. Fetal Hydrops
  6. Thick NT
  7. Previous baby with congenital heart disease (CHD)
  8. Either parent with CHD
  9. Conception through IVF
  10. Maternal anti Ro/ anti La
  11. Exposure to Lithium/ Anti-epileptic drugs/other teratogenic drugs
  12. Pregestational DM
  13. Phenylketonuria

Ref: Page no 201, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 1 – 2%
4 – 8%
5 – 10%
15 – 20%

questions.text: The risk of congenital anomalies in a woman taking sodium valproate is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5-10%

Congenital Malformations and Anti-Epileptic Drugs

 

Ref: Bhatia M, Adcock JE, Mackillop L. The management of pregnant women with epilepsy: a multidisciplinary collaborative approach to care. The Obstetrician & Gynaecologist 2017;19:279–88. DOI: 10.1111/tog.12413

choices.text: Routine monitoring of antiepileptic levels in the blood is not recommended
Epilepsy is an indication for cesarean section
Breastfeeding is not contra-indicated in women on antiepileptic drugs
Pre-conceptionally, switch from multidrug anti-epileptic therapy to monotherapy

questions.text: Regarding epilepsy in pregnancy, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Epilepsy is an indication for cesarean section.

  • Routine monitoring of anti-epileptic levels in the blood is not recommended
  • Epilepsy is not an indication for cesarean section
  • Breast feeding is safe in women on anti-epileptic drugs
  • Ideally pre-conceptionally, women on anti – epileptic drugs should be switched over to a single drug (monotherapy) with the least possible dose to prevent teratogenic effects on the fetus

Ref:  Williams Page no 2941 (Chapter 63), Williams 26th edition

choices.text: 24-hour Holter monitoring
Echocardiogram
Cardiac MRI
Treadmill stress test

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of congenital heart disease presents for her first prenatal visit. Which of the following is the most important initial evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Echocardiogram

 

Explanation: An echocardiogram uses ultrasound waves to create images of the heart and is essential for evaluating the structural and functional cardiac status in pregnant women with known heart disease. It helps in assessing ventricular function, valvular pathology, and any congenital abnormalities without exposing the fetus to radiation.

 

Other Options:  

 

  • Option A: 24-hour Holter Monitoring records the electrical activity of the heart over a 24-hour period using a portable device. It's useful for detecting arrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) that may not be captured during a brief ECG. However, while helpful in certain contexts, it does not provide information about the heart's structure or function, which is crucial in assessing congenital heart disease.
  • Option C: Cardiac MRI provides detailed images of the heart's structure and function and can be used for complex congenital heart disease evaluation. However, its use in pregnancy is generally limited due to concerns about the potential effects of the strong magnetic field and contrast agents on the fetus. Therefore, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool in pregnant women unless specifically indicated and after careful consideration of the risks and benefits.
  • Option D: Treadmill Stress Test assesses the heart's response to physical stress and is typically used to diagnose and evaluate coronary artery disease. It involves monitoring the heart while the patient walks on a treadmill with increasing speed and incline. However, it is not the primary tool for evaluating congenital heart disease and is less practical in pregnancy due to physical limitations and the risk of inducing stress on the cardiovascular system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate and important initial evaluation for a pregnant woman with a history of congenital heart disease.

 

Ref: Page no 951 , William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Anxiety attack
Peripartum cardiomyopathy
Pulmonary embolism
None of the above

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with no prior medical history suddenly develops dyspnea and chest pain at 32 weeks gestation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation: Pulmonary embolism is a common and serious condition in pregnancy due to hypercoagulability. Sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain are classic symptoms. Although peripartum cardiomyopathy (Option B) is a consideration, it typically presents later in the peripartum period or postpartum.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: While symptoms of an anxiety attack can mimic those of more serious conditions (like shortness of breath and chest pain), the sudden onset of these symptoms in a pregnant woman, particularly in the third trimester, warrants a thorough evaluation for more serious conditions first. Anxiety should be considered a diagnosis of exclusion in this context.
  • Option B: Peripartum Cardiomyopathy is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery. Symptoms include dyspnea, fatigue, and swelling in the legs and feet. It typically does not present suddenly but rather develops gradually.

 

Given the acute onset of dyspnea and chest pain in a pregnant woman in her third trimester, pulmonary embolism (Option C) should be considered the most likely diagnosis and warrants immediate medical evaluation due to its potentially life-threatening nature.Top of Form

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary Embolism in Pregnancy:

 

  • Causes 10% of maternal deaths in the developed world; up to 70% will have evidence of DVT
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms:  Dyspnea (most common symptom), chest pain, cough, syncope and hemoptysis
    • Signs:  Tachypnea, tachycardia. In some cases, an accentuated pulmonic closure sound, rales, and/or friction rub is heard.
       
  • ECG: Right axis deviation and T-wave inversion in the anterior chest leads
  • Chest X Ray: may be normal or nonspecific findings of atelectasis, an infiltrate, cardiomegaly, or an effusion. Vascular markings in the lung region supplied by the obstructed artery can be lost.
  • ECHO: Echocardiography is useful to detect other conditions that mimic pulmonary embolism—acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.
  • Diagnostic Tests: the American Society of Hematology recommends ventilation perfusion lung scanning as the first-line diagnostic tool. Other guidelines prefer CT-pulmonary angiography for suspected pulmonary embolism
  • Management:
    • Anti coagulation with heparin
    • Vena caval filter may be required
      • Prior to cesarean (As anti-coagulation may lead to torrential surgical hemorrhage)
      • If thrombolysis fails.

 

Ref: Page no 2571, William’s Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Mitral valve prolapse
Repaired atrial septal defect
Eisenmenger syndrome
Stable aortic stenosis

questions.text: Which heart condition is most associated with a high risk of mortality in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Eisenmenger syndrome

 

Explanation: Eisenmenger Syndrome is a serious condition where a congenital heart defect that initially causes left-to-right shunt (such as a ventricular septal defect, ASD, or patent ductus arteriosus) leading to pulmonary hypertension, resulting in the reversal of the shunt to a right-to-left shunt. This syndrome is associated with a significantly increased risk of mortality in pregnancy due to the severe strain it puts on the heart and lungs. Pregnancy is often contraindicated in women with Eisenmenger syndrome due to these risks.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Mitral Valve Prolapse is a condition in which the mitral valve leaflets bulge (prolapse) into the left atrium during the heart's contraction. Most women with mitral valve prolapse have a mild form and can go through pregnancy without significant complications.
  • Option B: An atrial septal defect (ASD) is a hole in the wall between the two upper chambers of the heart. If it has been repaired, the risk of complications during pregnancy is relatively low, especially if the repair was successful and there are no residual cardiac issues.
  • Option D: Aortic stenosis involves narrowing of the aortic valve, which can impede blood flow from the heart to the aorta and onward to the rest of the body. If the aortic stenosis is mild to moderate and stable, most women can tolerate pregnancy well. However, severe aortic stenosis can be risky during pregnancy, although not as high-risk as Eisenmenger syndrome.

 

Among these options, Eisenmenger syndrome (Option C) is the one most associated with a high risk of mortality in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This new classification of severity of heart disease in pregnancy by the WHO known as modified WHO risk stratification and os divided into 4 categories. Category 4 includes those diseases like Eisenmenger syndrome (Pulmonary artery HTN) where pregnancy is not recommended.

 

 

Ref: Page no 952, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Warfarin
Unfractionated heparin
Low molecular weight heparin
Direct oral anticoagulants

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a mechanical heart valve is being managed for anticoagulation. Which anticoagulant is preferred during the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Low molecular weight heparin

 

Explanation: Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is preferred in the first trimester due to the teratogenic effects of warfarin and better safety profile compared to unfractionated heparin. Direct oral anticoagulants are generally avoided in pregnancy.

 

  • Option A: Warfarin- This is preferred in non-pregnant women but it is teratogenic and can lead to warfarin embryopathy in doses > 5mg/ day. It is safe in the 2nd trimester but again in the 3rd trimester increases the risk of fetal hemorrhage
  • Option C: LMWH- This is insufficient to provide the coagulation needed for mechanical heart valves
  • Option D: Direct oral anticoagulants - (DOACs) are not recommended for use in mechanical heart valves and are also not recommended for use in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 2406, William’s Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Mild mitral regurgitation
Mitral stenosis with symptoms
Trivial aortic regurgitation
Small atrial septal defect

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents in her second trimester. Which of the following findings would most warrant intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mitral stenosis with symptoms

 

Explanation:

 

Mitral stenosis, which involves narrowing of the mitral valve, restricts blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. When symptomatic, it can lead to reduced cardiac output, pulmonary congestion, and even heart failure. Pregnancy increases the blood volume and heart rate, which can exacerbate these symptoms and complications. Severe symptomatic mitral stenosis often requires medical or even surgical intervention to manage the increased hemodynamic burden and to reduce the risk of maternal and fetal complications.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Mild mitral regurgitation, especially in the absence of symptoms, is usually well-tolerated during pregnancy and often does not require intervention. Pregnancy can increase the volume load on the heart, but mild regurgitation typically doesn't pose a significant risk.
  • Option C:  Trivial or mild aortic regurgitation typically does not pose a significant risk during pregnancy and often does not require intervention. The aortic valve allows blood to flow from the left ventricle to the aorta. If the regurgitation is only trivial, the heart can usually compensate well
  • Option D: A small ASD, a hole in the septum between the heart's two upper chambers (atria), often does not significantly impact hemodynamics, especially if there is no evidence of right heart overload or pulmonary hypertension. In most cases, a small ASD does not require intervention during pregnancy and is generally well-tolerated.

 

Among these options, severe mitral stenosis with symptoms (Option B) is the finding that most warrants intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral stenosis, which involves narrowing of the mitral valve, restricts blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. When symptomatic, it can lead to reduced cardiac output, pulmonary congestion, and even heart failure. Pregnancy increases the blood volume and heart rate, which can exacerbate these symptoms and complications. Severe symptomatic mitral stenosis often requires medical or even surgical intervention to manage the increased hemodynamic burden and to reduce the risk of maternal and fetal complications.

 

Ref: Page no 2390 , William’s Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Discontinue all antihypertensive medications
Strict protein restriction
Close monitoring of renal function and blood pressure
Routine dialysis for all patients

questions.text: Which of the following is a recommended management strategy for a pregnant woman with chronic kidney disease (CKD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Close monitoring of renal function and blood pressure

 

Explanation: For a pregnant woman with CKD, close monitoring of renal function and blood pressure is crucial. Management includes optimizing blood pressure control and monitoring for worsening renal function or the development of preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Discontinuation of all antihypertensive medications is not recommended. Many women with CKD require antihypertensive medications to control their blood pressure, which is crucial in preventing further renal damage and managing complications like preeclampsia. However, the choice of antihypertensive medication may need to be adjusted due to pregnancy, as some medications are contraindicated or not preferred during pregnancy.

 

Option B: Strict protein restriction: This approach is controversial and not generally recommended during pregnancy. While protein restriction can sometimes be beneficial in non-pregnant CKD patients to slow disease progression, during pregnancy, adequate protein intake is essential for fetal growth and development. Dietary modifications in pregnant CKD patients should be individualized and carefully balanced.

 

Option D: Starting or continuing dialysis in a pregnant woman with CKD depends on the severity of the renal impairment and is not routinely initiated based solely on the presence of CKD. Dialysis is typically reserved for those with advanced kidney failure or when there are indications such as refractory fluid overload, severe uremia, or life-threatening electrolyte imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prenatal care for women with CKD incorporates several important aspects.

 

  • Frequent monitoring of blood pressure is paramount, and serum creatinine levels and 24-hour protein excretion are quantified as indicated.
  • Bacteriuria is treated to lower the risk of pyelonephritis and further nephron loss.
  • Protein-restricted diets are not recommended.
  •  In some women with anemia from chronic renal insufficiency, a response is seen with recombinant erythropoietin.
  • Serial sonography is performed to follow fetal growth.
  • The differentiation between worsening hypertension and superimposed pre-eclampsia is problematic. Angiogenic biomarkers placental growth factor (PlGF) and its soluble receptor, soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1), may be useful to separate chronic from gestational hypertension

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 26th edition pg 2614

choices.text: Acute cystitis
Renal calculus
Acute pyelonephritis
Glomerulonephritis

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no prior history of renal disease develops sudden onset of flank pain and hematuria in her second trimester. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B. Renal calculus

 

Explanation: Sudden onset flank pain and hematuria in a pregnant woman with no prior renal disease history are suggestive of a renal calculus (kidney stone). Pregnancy increases the risk of kidney stones due to changes in urinary tract physiology.

 

Other options:

 

Option A:  Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder that often presents with symptoms like urinary frequency, urgency, dysuria (painful urination), and suprapubic pain. Hematuria can sometimes be present, but acute cystitis typically does not cause flank pain. Flank pain is more characteristic of upper urinary tract infections or obstructions, such as pyelonephritis or renal stones.

 

Option C:  Acute Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the kidneys and is a more severe form of urinary tract infection. While it can cause flank pain and hematuria, it typically also presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms such as nausea and vomiting. The sudden onset of severe pain is more characteristic of renal calculus than acute pyelonephritis, which often has a more gradual onset.

 

Option D: Glomerulonephritis is an inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It can present with hematuria, proteinuria, and sometimes hypertension. However, it is less likely to cause sudden onset flank pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden onset flank pain and hematuria in a pregnant woman with no prior renal disease history are suggestive of a renal calculus (kidney stone). Pregnancy increases the risk of kidney stones due to changes in urinary tract physiology.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg1030
